description: From Middle English lightnen, equivalent to light +‎ -en.

verbs.description: lighten (third-person singular simple present lightens, present participle lightening, simple past and past participle lightened)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make brighter or clearer; to illuminate.
examples: to lighten an apartment with lamps or gas; to lighten the streets

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become brighter or clearer; to brighten.
(intransitive, now rare) To flash lightning, to give off lightning.
examples: While we were in the Twins it began to thunder and lighten and pour with rain.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To emit or disclose in, or as if in, lightning; to flash out, like lightning.
To illuminate with knowledge; to enlighten.
examples: O Light which mak’st the Light, which makes the Day,
Which setst the Eye without and Mind within,
Lighten my spirit with one cleare heavenly ray,
Which now to view it selfe doth first begin.

description: From Middle English lightnen, equivalent to light +‎ -en.

verbs.description: lighten (third-person singular simple present lightens, present participle lightening, simple past and past participle lightened)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To alleviate; to reduce the burden of.
examples: Sorrow can be lightened by being openly brought out.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make light or lighter in weight.
(transitive) To make less serious or more cheerful.
(intransitive) To become light or lighter in weight.
(intransitive) To become less serious or more cheerful.

verbs.description: lighten (third-person singular simple present lightens, present participle lightening, simple past and past participle lightened)

examples: O Lord, let thy mercy lighten upon us.
